did.unittitle: Indiana University Folklore Institute's Ventriloquism Project records
did.abstract: The Ventriloquism Project was a planned collaboration of the Indiana University Folklore Institute and Radio & TV Services, who hoped to produce a documentary on the contemporary practice of ventriloquism in the United States. Ultimately, the project was not funded. This collection traces the history of the venture from its beginnings to its eventual shelving.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. Advance notice required.

bioghist.head: Administrative History
bioghist.p: The Ventriloquism Project was a planned collaboration of the Folklore Institute and Radio & TV Services, who hoped to produce a documentary on the contemporary practice of ventriloquism in the United States. Ultimately, the project was not funded. This collection traces the history of the venture from its beginnings to its eventual shelving.

The materials included here are among the last describing the Folklore Institute's documentary filmmaking activities in the 1980s. Some of the most successful of the Institute's documentary projects were 1980's Joy Unspeakable, which investigated Pentecostal traditions in southern Indiana; and 1983's Classics Come Home: Auburn, Cord, Duesenberg, which highlighted automotive heritage in northern Indiana.

Participants in the Ventriloquism Project worked hard to turn their idea into a documentary. The files in this collection—especially those in Series 2—detail their efforts to solicit financial support from a wide variety of sources. Even though they were unsuccessful in the end, this collection is valuable in that it archives a substantial body of preliminary work. Practitioners or fans of ventriloquism, as well as folklorists or other cultural experts with an interest in performance studies, are likely to find this material stimulating. Scholarly essays, event programs, and individual performers' publicity pamphlets are among the files.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into two series: Background materials, and Project overview and correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This collection is organized into two series. The first series, Background materials, includes promotional literature, media coverage, and academic publications related to ventriloquism, as well as preliminary research data gathered at Vent Haven, a ventriloquism museum in Fort Mitchell, Kentucky. It spans 1973-1987. The second series, Project overview and correspondence, details project participants' search for funding through various sources, including master puppeteer Jim Henson. A full project proposal is also included with these files, which span 1987-1990. All materials are arranged to reflect the movement of the project from ideation to attempted execution.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: Two audio cassettes in an envelope dated July 15, 1985, and labeled "FCM Conference"; located in Folder "Audio cassettes" (Box 2).
Photographs Pulled: 3 contact sheets, 11 strips of negatives, and 1 photograph, all located in Folder "Photos & negatives" (Box 2). No contextual information.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
